importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault at Gettysburg College occurred, marking the beginning of a prolonged legal and emotional journey for the victim.
The year when Ian Cleary sent the Facebook message 'So I raped you' to Shannon Keeler, triggering renewed efforts to pursue legal action.
The year when Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story, highlighting systemic failures in prosecuting campus sexual assaults.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy-related charge, which led to his eventual extradition to the U.S. for the sexual assault case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time span from the initial assault to the 2025 sentencing reflects the long-term impact of campus sexual assault and the systemic delays in prosecution.
The period during which Cleary sent the Facebook message and Keeler reactivated legal action reveals ongoing trauma and the persistence of accountability efforts.

keyTakeAways: A man who sexually assaulted a college student in 2013 was sentenced to two to four years in prison after being extradited from France, highlighting the difficulty of tracking offenders over time.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent 12 years pursuing justice, illustrating the real-world consequences of delayed prosecution and the emotional toll on survivors.
The case underscores systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases, including the destruction of forensic evidence and prosecutors’ reluctance to file charges.

Cleary’s guilty plea, remorse, and mental health history influenced the judge’s decision to impose a sentence below state guidelines, indicating the role of rehabilitation and contrition in sentencing.
The Facebook message 'So I raped you' was sent as part of a 12-step program, raising questions about the ethics and effectiveness of such atonement efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2013, Ian Cleary sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College, an incident that went unprosecuted for over a decade due to systemic failures in campus sexual assault cases. Keeler, who began pursuing charges immediately after the assault, was ultimately able to press forward after an Associated Press story in 2021 highlighted the reluctance of prosecutors to act. Cleary was tracked down in France in 2024 through an unrelated vagrancy arrest and extradited to Pennsylvania, where he pleaded guilty to second-degree sexual assault in 2025. A judge sentenced him to two to four years in prison, citing his remorse, guilty plea, and history of mental illness, while noting that the case exposed deep flaws in how such crimes are handled, including lost forensic evidence and prolonged delays. The case underscores the emotional toll on survivors and the urgent need for reform in campus sexual assault response systems.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After 12-Year Campus Sexual Assault Case, Facebook Message Sparks Justice
